<<<code>>>: import java.awt.event.KeyEvent;
import java.awt.event.KeyListener;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;

public class Example implements KeyListener {
    Map<Integer, Boolean> keyState = new HashMap<>();

    public void keyTyped(KeyEvent e) {}

    public void keyPressed(KeyEvent e) {
        if (keyState.get(e.getKeyCode()) == null || !keyState.get(e.getKeyCode())) {
            System.out.println("KeyPressed: " + e.getKeyCode() + ", ts=" + e.getWhen());
            keyState.put(e.getKeyCode(), true);
        }
    }

    public void keyReleased(KeyEvent e) {
        System.out.println("KeyReleased: " + e.getKeyCode() + ", ts=" + e.getWhen());
        keyState.put(e.getKeyCode(), false);
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: In this code, a Map is used to keep track of the state of each key. When a key is pressed, the code checks if the key is already in the pressed state in the Map. If it is not, it logs the key press and sets the state to true. When a key is released, it logs the key release and sets the state to false. This way, repeated key press events caused by holding down a key are ignored.
